zone.line: the shutters had been thrown back and with
a sensation of horror not to be described I
saw at the open window a figure the most
hideous & abhorred – A grin was on the face
of the monster. that he seemed to jeer as with
his fiendish finger he pointed towards the
corpse of my wife—I rushed towards the window
and drawing a pistol from my bosom –shot–
but he eluded me – he leapt from his station
and run running with ^ the swiftness of lightning
plunged in to the lake. The report of my
pistol brought a crowed into the room
I pointed to where he had disappeared &
we followed him with boats & cast nets
but in vain and passing several hours
re in the search returned hopeless – m M ost
of my companions believeing it to have
been a form conjured by my fancy. How
ever after having quitte landed they pro
ceeded to search the country goin parties
going in different directions among the
woods & vines. I did not accompany them
for the exhaustion that now seized on
me I was exhausted; a film covered my
eyes and my skin burned was parched with t the heat
of fever. In this state I lay on a bed hardly
conscious of what had happened & my eyes
wandered round the room as if to seek
somthing that I had lost. At length I remem
bered that my father would anxiously
expect the return of Elizabeth & myself
and that I must return alone. This
reflection brought tears into my eyes & I
wept for a long time. I reflected o m n my
misfortunes & their cause and was bewildered
